newsitem.title: USA: Ford exec says yen fluctuations a fact of life.
newsitem.headline: Ford exec says yen fluctuations a fact of life.

text.p: U.S. automakers must work to stay competitive no matter how much the yen-dollar exchange rate fluctuates, a top Ford Motor Co executive said Thursday.

In contrast to comments made Wednesday by General Motors Corp, Ross Roberts, vice president and general manager of the Ford Division, told reporters at the Chicago Auto Show that the yen's current weakness against the dollar is "a fact of life."

The exchange rate of about 123 yen to the dollar is currently giving an advantage to Japanese automakers, Roberts said, but he noted that U.S. automakers had an advantage when the rate was 85 to the dollar two years ago.
"We have to learn to compete with fluctuations in currencies around the world. That's part of our life," Roberts said.

On Wednesday, GM North American Operations President G. Richard Wagoner said the yen's weakness was the result of a concerted effort by Japan's Ministry of Finance and was giving an unfair advantage to Japanese automakers.

The heightened concern among executives of Detroit's Big Three automakers comes on the heels of significant market share gains by several Japanese automakers in the United States in January, particularly by Toyota Motor Corp and Honda Motor Co Ltd.
